newsitem.title: USA: Western U.S. spot power steady amid slower demand.
newsitem.headline: Western U.S. spot power steady amid slower demand.

text.p: West Coast spot power prices were largely steady Wednesday amid lower hydroelectric generation in the Northwest and moderate temperatures through much of the region.
Weaker natural gas prices were also seen offsetting short-covering by power marketers in the Southwest.

The Bonneville Power Administration withdrew from offering next-day pre-scheduled power during peak-demand hours, but did offer up to 600 megawatts during early morning hours on Thursday at $13.00 per megawatt hour (MWh).
"Until the end of August we were forced to generate more power than we needed," said Bonneville spokesman Hugh Moore.
"Now we are in water management mode and have no reason to market surplus power."

Next-day firm prices at Mid-Columbia were quoted $18.50-19.00 per megawatt hour, down from $19.50 on Tuesday. California-Oregon border power was quoted little changed from Tuesday at $18.50-19.00 on Tuesday.
Next-day Palo Verde was unchanged near $27.00.
Cash PV for October was last seen at $16.55-16.80, while COB was at $15.70-16.20.
"Gas prices are coming off and loads are down," said one electricity trader. "I expect prices to continue trending downward."
He sees October COB prices falling to $14.00 or lower, with Palo Verde dropping as low as $13.00.
Southwest spot natural gas prices are now seen near $1.60 per million British thermal units, compared with $2.00 in August, traders noted.
"Utilities are making a lot of money selling power at $26.00," said another trader.
"There seems to be more of a lack of water (for hydroelectric generation) than people expected."
